results.title: Hades

constellations_other.name: Iconic creative partnerships
constellations_other.description: Actor Nicholas Hoult and writer-director Tony Mcnamara worked on The Favourite together before Hoult was cast in The Great. Strong creative partnerships between particular actors and directors are the backbone of screen creativity.

results.description: A rogue-lite hack and slash dungeon crawler in which Zagreus, son of Hades the Greek god of the dead, attempts to escape his home and his oppressive father by fighting the souls of the dead through the various layers of the ever-shifting underworld, while getting to know and forging relationships with its inhabitants.
description_for_label: A rogue-lite hack and slash dungeon crawler in which Zagreus, son of Hades the Greek god of the dead, attempts to escape his home and his oppressive father by fighting the souls of the dead through the various layers of the ever-shifting underworld, while getting to know and forging relationships with its inhabitants.

results.title: Collective
results.description: In Collective, documentarian Alexander Nanau follows a team of journalists who uncover a far-reaching government conspiracy following a deadly nightclub fire in Romania which kills dozens.
description_for_label: In Collective, documentarian Alexander Nanau follows a team of journalists who uncover a far-reaching government conspiracy following a deadly nightclub fire in Romania which kills dozens.

results.brief_description:
The official music video for Charli XCX & Troye Sivan - “1999”.

Taken from the third studio album Charli, released in 2019. Charli featured the singles “1999”, “Blame It On Your Love”, “Gone” and “White Mercedes.”

constellations_other.name: Faking history
constellations_other.description: The Great takes a creative approach to its historical characters and settings that is mirrored in its costumes - this war dress might have a classic silhouette, but the grimy pearlescent fabric and striking oxblood detailing is completely modern. Faking history is a time-honoured tradition in film, from historical fiction to propaganda.

results.title: Maps Against the World (2016)
results.credit_line:
Director: Woo-Suk Kang

Writers: Jung-mi Choi (screenplay); Beom-shin Park (novel)

Starring: Seung-Won Cha; Shin Dong-mi; Kim In-kwon
results.brief_description: Director Woo-Suk Kang’s 2016 documentary tells the story of the real cartographer Kim Jeong-Ho who mapped the islands of Korea in the nineteenth century. In a period when only royalty and governments held the knowledge held in maps, Jeong-Ho wanted to make maps to empower ordinary Koreans to mark their land and to travel safely. Maps embody knowledge, in stories and beyond.

constellations_other.name: The narrative power of maps
constellations_other.description: Maps are designed to communicate complex information in a clear manner to aid both navigation and wayfinding and knowledge of place.

results.description: Director Woo-Suk Kang’s 2016 film tells the true story of the 19th century cartographer Kim Jeong-Ho, who mapped the islands of Korea. Maps embody knowledge, in stories and beyond.

constellations_other.name: Dress to impress
constellations_other.description: In The Great, Peter and Catherine’s costumes during their Dacha visit are designed to demonstrate their unity, as they negotiate with the Swedish royals. Clothes have long been a way to communicate power, particularly in politics.

results.title_for_label: Representative Ilhan Omar wins the right to wear Hijab in the House chamber
results.description: When she was elected to US Congress, representative Ilhan Omar successfully fought for her right to wear a hijab in the House chamber of the Capitol. Previously, headwear was banned in the House, but Omar, the first Muslim woman in US congress alongside Rep. Rashida Tlaib, successfully fought for a religious exemption: “No one puts a scarf on my head but me. It’s my choice—one protected by the first amendment,” she wrote on Twitter to announce the change.
description_for_label: When she was elected to US Congress, representative Ilhan Omar successfully fought for her right to wear a hijab in the House chamber of the Capitol. Previously, headwear was banned in the House, but Omar, the first Muslim woman in US congress alongside Rep. Rashida Tlaib, successfully fought for a religious exemption: “No one puts a scarf on my head but me. It’s my choice—one protected by the first amendment,” she wrote on Twitter to announce the change.

results.title: The Mew conspiracy
results.brief_description: When the original Pokemon games Red and Blue were released, players theorised widely about the whereabouts of Mew, the elusive 151st pokemon. One theory was that Mew was hiding under a hard-to-find truck near the SS Anne. When remakes FireRed and LeafGreen were released in 2004, players found the truck again. On examination, players are rewarded, not with a rare Pokemon, but with a cookie, as a nod to the conspiracy.

results.title: Project Archive
results.brief_description: The project archive of Brisbane programmer, Nick Marentes, tells the story behind the creation of each of his homebrew games, as well as his hopes and dreams of becoming a millionaire. Marentes wrote games for the Tandy range of computers, beginning with the TRS-80.

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

results.title: The Soundmaker (2004)
results.material_description:
3-channel film installation
Colour, sound
Loop, 35 min 7 sec
While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making.
results.brief_description: The Soundmaker (2004) is the first part of Rosefeldt’s Trilogy of Failure (2004/2005) in which three different settings draw a picture of our vain entanglement with everyday rituals.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description:
The Soundmaker (2004) is the first part of Rosefeldt’s Trilogy of Failure (2004/2005) in which three different settings draw a picture of our vain entanglement with everyday rituals. In each case the protagonist is caught up in a microcosm that suggests mental and spatial claustrophobia. As a reaction to the hopeless situation, he plunges into permanent Sisyphean activity – going nowhere and producing nothing. The motifs of perpetual attempt and constant failure find their equivalent in the repetitive structure of the loop. The scenes are allegories of our frantic and ultimately futile attempts to escape the surrounding norms, constraints, structures and rituals by which we are determined.

The Soundmaker piles, in endless iteration, the furnishings of his room into his own personal Tower of Babel, only to dismantle it and return the room to its original state again. His performance is accompanied by a Foley artist, an alter ego looking identical to himself. While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making. Shot in aerial and frontal perspective, the screens depict the translation from life as it occurs in the centre into simple objects and minimal movements. As in many of his latter projects, Rosefeldt reflects upon the myth machinery of cinema by showing the film set behind the scenes, while simultaneously using it as a metaphor for the mechanics of life.

Summarised from Stefan Berg and Katerina Gregos, in: Julian Rosefeldt: Film Works (2008).

  • https://www.julianrosefeldt.com/

The motifs of perpetual attempt and constant failure find their equivalent in the repetitive structure of the loop. The scenes are allegories of our frantic and ultimately futile attempts to escape the surrounding norms, constraints, structures and rituals by which we are determined.

The Soundmaker piles, in endless iteration, the furnishings of his room into his own personal Tower of Babel, only to dismantle it and return the room to its original state again. While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making. results.title: After the Apology

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description: Suellyn thought FACS would only remove children in extreme cases until her own grandchildren were taken. Hazel decided to take on the FACS system after her fourth grandchild was taken into state care. Jen Swan was raising her grandchildren until she was deemed unsuitable by FACS. The rate of Indigenous child removal has increased at an exponential rate since Prime Minister Kevin Rudd delivered the apology to the ‘stolen generations’ in 2008. Hazel started GMAR as a response to the rising rates of child removal and along the way she has been joined by families across Australia in the battle to bring the kids home. Together are not only taking on the system, they are changing it.
